title: Variant
data:
[![](/images/thumb/5/5a/VariantHistoryGraph.jpg/400px-VariantHistoryGraph.jpg)](/wiki/File:VariantHistoryGraph.jpg)



The history of NetHack variant development in all its convoluted glory, as of February 2023. Black arrows indicate direct descent from a whole codebase; gray indicate inspiration or scattered features copied in.

A **variant** (also sometimes known as a fork, mod, or patchset) is a copy of *NetHack* to which substantial code changes have been made.

Most variants make changes to the gameplay, but this isn't a requirement: [NitroHack](/wiki/NitroHack "NitroHack"), for instance, is a variant which makes huge code changes but does not change gameplay at all.

The [NetHack General Public License](/wiki/NetHack_General_Public_License "NetHack General Public License") allows anyone to create a variant, provided that they use the same license. Then, features from that variant may be reused in other variants!

Variants are distinct from [patches](/wiki/Patch "Patch"). A variant typically contains a large amount of changes and has a broader goal, whereas a patch does one specific thing and contains only the changes required to make it work. Some variants were formed by applying multiple existing patches to the vanilla source code.

A variant is either distributed as a very large patch against vanilla *NetHack* (uncommon nowadays), or as a separate source code distribution such as a public Git repository.

All variants to date have the same overall goal that vanilla *NetHack* does: to enter [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), retrieve the [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor"), and bring it to the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane").

If you are thinking about making a variant, consider consulting active variant developers on [Libera](/wiki/Libera "Libera") for advice and early feedback on your ideas.

[ ]

## Actively developed variants

These are variants that have added new features (not just bugfixes) in the last year.

### [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack")

| dNetHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project's GitHub page](https://github.com/Chris-plus-alphanumericgibberish/dNAO)
- maintained by [Chris](/wiki/User:Chris "User:Chris")
- current version 3.23.0
- variant of [nethack.alt.org](/wiki/Nethack.alt.org "Nethack.alt.org") version of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

*dNetHack* is a variant that does five main things: it greatly increases the number of artifacts, implements new monsters, re-organizes and expands the dungeon, attempts to re-balance armors, item appearances, and intrinsics to make more choices viable in the late game, and replaces the [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") mechanic with warding signs. It also incorporates the [Pirate](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate") and [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict") patches, and makes a few minor changes in existing classes and items.

Most new artifacts have custom effects and/or invocations. Most new monsters have new attacks or other code support. Dungeon changes include: multi-level alignment “quest” branches, additional side branches off the main dungeon, and a shortened [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), with demon lairs randomly drawn from a small pool and fewer straight-up maze levels.

dNetHack incorporates code from many other variants and patches, such as [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), and implements many [YANIs](/wiki/YANI "YANI") from this wiki and from [rec.games.roguelike.nethack](/wiki/Rec.games.roguelike.nethack "Rec.games.roguelike.nethack").

Discuss the variant at <irc://libera.chat/dnethack>. It is playable at [hardfought](/wiki/Hardfought "Hardfought").

### [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack")

| EvilHack                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [GitHub](https://github.com/k21971/EvilHack)
- maintained by [K2](/wiki/User:K2 "User:K2")
- current version 0.8.3
- variant of [NetHack 3.6.7](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.7 "NetHack 3.6.7") post-release version |

*EvilHack* is a variant based on [NetHack 3.6.7](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.7 "NetHack 3.6.7").

EvilHack was designed from the outset to be a much more difficult game to win than vanilla *NetHack*. The inspiration for this game mainly comes from the variants GruntHack and SporkHack, incorporating many of the same features that make those variants difficult in their own right. Some of those features have remained the same (for example, SporkHack's reflection changes), but many have been altered to set them apart and provide the player with a new experience. Elements from other variants have been included as well, such as from Slash'EM, SpliceHack, UnNetHack, and xNetHack. There is also a significant amount of custom content that has been developed that is not found in any other variant. More custom content will be added as development continues, mainly in the way of optional branch quests.

EvilHack features new races and roles, new items (including [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") and [object properties](/wiki/Object_properties "Object properties")), an improved monster AI, a revamped [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), several new monsters, and adds exciting and challenging experiences to virtually every aspect of vanilla *NetHack*. It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") server.

### [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack")

| FIQHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project's GitHub page](https://github.com/FredrIQ/fiqhack)
- maintained by [FredrIQ](https://github.com/FredrIQ) a.k.a. [FIQ](/wiki/User:FIQ "User:FIQ")
- current version 4.3.1
- variant of [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4") |

*FIQHack* is a variant of [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4") that has 3 main focuses: improving convenience and quality of life, improving monster AI and behaviour, and improving monster/player symmetry (i.e. making things behave the same for both). Aside from this, there have also been various other gameplay tweaks, as well as improvement of code quality.

A comprehensive changelog of every notable change in FIQHack can be found in its [article](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack").

### [GnollHack](/wiki/GnollHack "GnollHack")

| GnollHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project's GitHub wiki page](https://github.com/hyvanmielenpelit/GnollHack/wiki)
- maintained by [Sound Mind Games](https://hyvanmielenpelit.fi/tule-mukaan/pienkannatusjaseneksi/in-english)
- current version 4.1.3.16
- variant of [NetHack 3.6.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.2 "NetHack 3.6.2") |

*GnollHack* is a variant of *NetHack* 3.6.2 developed by Sound Mind Games, a Finnish nonprofit organization. It adds numerous monsters and items, changes spellcasting, and adds Gnolls as a playable race (replacing Gnomes).

### [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack")

| notdNetHack                                                                                                                                                                               |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project's GitHub page](https://github.com/demogorgon22/notdnethack)
- maintained by Demo
- current version 2024.05.15 (date format)
- variant of [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") |

*notdNetHack* is a dNetHack fork that seeks to add more depth to the existing content of dNetHack while balancing and trimming out some of its points of failure. notdNetHack attempts to add fully complete features and content that feel like they belong with the existing dNetHack base while not being afraid to be different.

It is playable on the [em.slashem.me](/wiki/Em.slashem.me "Em.slashem.me") and [hardfought.org](/wiki/Hardfought.org "Hardfought.org") servers.

### [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack")

| notnotdNetHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project's Codeberg page](https://codeberg.org/noisytoot/notnotdnethack)
- maintained by [Noisytoot](/index.php?title=User:Noisytoot\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "User:Noisytoot (page does not exist)")
- current version 2024.05.15 (date format)
- variant of [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") |

*notnotdNetHack* is a variant of [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack").

It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Hardfought "Hardfought") server.

### [Slash'EM Extended](/wiki/Slash%27EM_Extended "Slash'EM Extended")

| Slash'EM Extended                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - maintained by [Bluescreenofdeath](/wiki/User:Bluescreenofdeath "User:Bluescreenofdeath") a.k.a. Amy or AmyBSOD
- current version 2.8.9
- variant of [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") 0.0.7E7F2 |

*Slash'EM Extended* is a variant of [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM").

Compared to SLASH'EM, Slash'EM Extended contains many new roles and races for the player to choose from, many new special levels, a lot of new monsters, and other changes (similar goals to the original SLASH'EM, which also aimed at adding lots of stuff, so this has even more). The main [dungeon](/wiki/Dungeon "Dungeon") is a bit shorter in Slash'EM Extended than in SLASH'EM but the Gehennom is longer (making their lengths more like in vanilla [NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")), and the demon/devil lairs appear in a random order.

### [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack")

| UnNetHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Official blog](http://unnethack.wordpress.com/), [Github page](https://github.com/UnNetHack/UnNetHack)
- maintained by [Patric Müller](http://bhaak.net/) a.k.a.[Bhaak](/wiki/User:Bhaak "User:Bhaak")
- current version 6.0.8
- variant of [NetHack 3.6.6](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.6 "NetHack 3.6.6") |

*UnNetHack* is a variant whose main intent is to put more randomness, challenges and fun into *NetHack*. UnNetHack incorporates many changes from other variants and patches as well as its own to form a fun and balanced variant. In the era of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), it was described as “how *NetHack* would look today if the [DevTeam](/wiki/DevTeam "DevTeam") didn't stop releasing”, but then the DevTeam [did keep releasing](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"), and brought in content from UnNetHack to boot. It is the most famous and popular of the actively developed variants, and frequently shares with and borrows from other variants.

Discuss the variant at <irc://libera.chat/unnethack>.

It features more levels, several UI improvements, and a lot of game play related changes. It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") server.

### [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack")

| xNetHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project GitHub](https://github.com/copperwater/xNetHack)
- maintained by aosdict a.k.a [Phol ende wodan](/wiki/User:Phol_ende_wodan "User:Phol ende wodan")
- current version 8.0.0
- variant of [NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0") development version |

*xNetHack* is the first variant to be based on [NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0").

Its main goals are to fix balance problems in vanilla and remove sources of frustration, as well as experimenting with [YANIs](/wiki/YANI "YANI") from the community. It also follows a unique development model of remaining up-to-date with the latest code added to vanilla, rather than being based on a static release; consequently, new features and improvements in vanilla always get included in xNetHack soon after they are added.

Some of its features include special rooms in maze levels, an overhauled spellcasting system, several new conducts, and several UI enhancements. It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") server.

### [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM")

| Hack'EM                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [GitHub](https://github.com/nethack-cleaner/HackEM)
- maintained by [malor](/index.php?title=User:Malor\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "User:Malor (page does not exist)")
- current version 1.3.1
- variant of [Evilhack](/wiki/Evilhack "Evilhack") post-release version |

*Hack'EM* is a variant based on [Evilhack](/wiki/Evilhack "Evilhack").

It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Hardfought "Hardfought") [public server](/wiki/Public_server "Public server").

## Maintained variants

These variants haven't added any new features in the past year, but someone is still fixing bugs.

### [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack")

| GruntHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Home page](https://github.com/sgrunt/GruntHack/), [updated/maintained version](https://github.com/k21971/GruntHack/)
- maintained by [SGrunt](/wiki/User:SGrunt "User:SGrunt"), then later [K2](/wiki/User:K2 "User:K2") and Tangles
- current version 0.3.0
- variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

*GruntHack* is a variant intended to extend and enhance the game's existing behavior rather than altering it in any thoroughly substantial way, such as [objects](/wiki/Object "Object") of the same object type being made from different [materials](/wiki/Material "Material") and occasionally possessing [non-standard powers](/wiki/Object_properties "Object properties"), [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") having [different races](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") and using more tactics when fighting other monsters, and more intelligent pet behavior.

Though it enables the player to become significantly more powerful than in vanilla, a number of its changes add significant challenges to the early and late game, making it one of the most difficult variants.

There are [public servers](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") at [ssh nethack@hardfought.org](ssh://nethack@hardfought.org) (USA) and [ssh slashem@slashem.me](ssh://slashem@slashem.me).

### [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4")

| NetHack 4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Home page](http://nethack4.org/) and [repository](http://trac.nethack4.org/browser)
- maintained by [Ais523](/wiki/User:Ais523 "User:Ais523")
- current version [4.3-beta2](http://nethack4.org/releases/4.3-beta2.html)
- variant of [AceHack](/wiki/AceHack "AceHack") and [NitroHack](/wiki/NitroHack "NitroHack") (merged) |

*NetHack 4* is a merge of [AceHack](/wiki/AceHack "AceHack") and [NitroHack](/wiki/NitroHack "NitroHack"), and the official successor to both projects. It aims for gameplay similar to *NetHack* but with an improved interface. It combines the interface improvements and gameplay changes of AceHack (see its section) with the persistent inventory, larger message box, new status display, new options interface, fully remappable keys, new main menu and other features of NitroHack.

It can be played online on its [public server](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") using [telnet nethack4.org](telnet://nethack4.org/) or [ssh nethack43@nethack4.org](ssh://nethack43@nethack4.org) (password "nethack43") or via [ssh nethack@hardfought.org](ssh://nethack@hardfought.org) (USA).

For command-line Git access, use `git clone nethack4.org/media/nethack4.git`.

### [NetHack Fourk](/wiki/NetHack_Fourk "NetHack Fourk")

| NetHack Fourk                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [github page](https://github.com/tsadok/nhfourk)
- maintained by [Jonadab](/wiki/User:Jonadab "User:Jonadab")
- current version 4.3.0.5
- variant of [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4") |

*NetHack Fourk* is an experimental fork of [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4"). It has four main types of changes: balance adjustments and formula tweaks; differentiation of similar monsters, objects, and levels; consolidation of boring things; and monster letter reorganization. A lot of game mechanics work slightly differently than players tend to be used to. See [the changelog](https://github.com/tsadok/nhfourk/blob/bleeding-edge/doc/changelog-fourk.txt) for details.

It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") server.

### [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM")

| SLASH'EM                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Home page](http://www.slashem.org)
- maintained by [Warren Cheung a.k.a. wacko](https://sourceforge.net/u/wacko/profile/)
- current version 0.0.8E0F1
- variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

*Slash'EM* or *SLASH'EM*, officially *SuperLotsaAddedStuffHack - Extended Magic*, used to be the foremost variant. This game and its ancestor variants are now part of vanilla *NetHack*'s [game history](/wiki/Game_history "Game history"), because of the reuse of certain SLASH'EM code in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0").

SLASH'EM puts more effort into killing the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero"); plenty of games end on dungeon level 1. There are more than plenty of new [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster"), [items](/wiki/Item "Item") and [magic](/wiki/Magic "Magic"). The dungeon features several new one-level dungeon branches for the hero to die in. Three new [portals](/wiki/Portal "Portal") lead to quests for [artifact keys](/wiki/Alignment_key "Alignment key"). The player also has a larger choice of [races](/wiki/Race "Race") and [roles](/wiki/Role "Role") than in vanilla, and that alone is enough to make an experienced NetHack player rethink [strategy](/wiki/Strategy "Strategy").

SLASH'EM started as a combination of two other variants, **[SLASH](/wiki/SLASH "SLASH")** and the **[Wizard Patch](/wiki/Wizard_Patch "Wizard Patch")**. In turn, SLASH was a merger of and addition to **[NetHack Plus](/wiki/NetHack_Plus "NetHack Plus")** and **[NetHack--](/wiki/NetHack-- "NetHack--")**.

SLASH'EM recently switched from 'unmaintained' to 'maintained' status, with the advent of several recent commits that have addressed several bugs. The updated/maintained version can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") server. An older, unmaintained version can be found at [em.slashem.me](/wiki/Em.slashem.me "Em.slashem.me").

### [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack")

| SporkHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Archived home page](https://web.archive.org/web/20150212195235/http://www.sporkhack.com/), [github source](https://github.com/k21971/SporkHack)
- maintained by Derek S. Ray, then later [K2](/wiki/User:K2 "User:K2") and Tangles
- current version 0.7.0
- variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

*SporkHack* is a variant actively developed and tested until December 2011; development was started up again in July of 2017 by community members Tangles and K2. The stated purpose of the variant is to try to bring more challenge to the vanilla game for experienced players, as well as to make things less boring for *all* players. A patch and a Windows binary are available from the home page; the patch can be applied to a standard NetHack 3.4.3 distribution. SporkHack contains "more interesting" [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman") and [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight") roles, and a number of balance adjustments throughout the game to spells, monsters and items... as well as intangibles such as the "to hit" formula. There are also cosmetic changes, for example the [master lich](/wiki/Master_lich "Master lich") is a [green L](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/browse_thread/thread/8766fa58e6b4caec/36ad820692d27fd2).

Latest development of SporkHack includes bugfixes and functionality enhancement; no changes affecting gameplay or the original author's intent have been made at this time. The repository for version 0.7.0 can be found on [GitHub](https://github.com/k21971/SporkHack).

The latest developed version (0.7.0) can be played online at the hardfought.org [public server](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") via [ssh nethack@hardfought.org](ssh://nethack@hardfought.org) (discussion in [#hardfought](irc://libera.chat/#hardfought) on [Libera](/wiki/Libera "Libera")). The older version (0.6.3) can be played online on the em.slashem.me [public server](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") using [ssh slashem@slashem.me](ssh://slashem@slashem.me).

### [3.4.3-HDF](/wiki/Nethack.alt.org#NetHack_3.4.3_NAO "Nethack.alt.org")

Not a seperate variant per se, but a maintained version of 3.4.3-NAO hosted on [hardfought](/wiki/Hardfought "Hardfought") which still gets bug fixes as needed.

## Unmaintained variants

These variants aren't being updated at all. Some of them may still have lots of players.

### [AceHack](/wiki/AceHack "AceHack")

| AceHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Source code Git repository](https://github.com/deepy/acehack)
- formerly maintained by [Ais523](/wiki/User:Ais523 "User:Ais523")
- current version 3.6.0
- variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

*AceHack* is a variant of *NetHack* that has similar gameplay to NetHack 3.4.3 but an improved interface, e.g. walking into doors opens them automatically, background colors to distinguish [tame](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness")/[peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful")/[hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile") monsters and stairs under items, describing what's under the cursor while moving it in [farlook](/wiki/Farlook "Farlook"), and warning before moving into lava. It also includes gameplay changes such as rerolling for items and attributes during character generation, auto-identifying some items under circumstances where the identity is unambiguous, making [floating eyes](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye") unhittable instead of [paralyzing](/wiki/Paralysis "Paralysis"), replacing [Stormbringer](/wiki/Stormbringer "Stormbringer")'s disabling of the peaceful attack warning prompt with [aggravate monster](/wiki/Aggravate_monster "Aggravate monster") when wielded, and replacing map and item identity [amnesia](/wiki/Scroll_of_amnesia "Scroll of amnesia") with draining of skill and spell training.

Development of AceHack has stopped in favor of [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4"), itself a merge of AceHack and [NitroHack](/wiki/NitroHack "NitroHack").

As of July 2022, AceHack can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") server.

### [DNHslex](/wiki/DNHslex "DNHslex")

| DNHslex                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| - [Project's GitHub page](https://github.com/AmyBSOD/dnhslex)
- maintained by [Bluescreenofdeath](/wiki/User:Bluescreenofdeath "User:Bluescreenofdeath")
- current version 3.16.1
- variant of [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") |

*DNHslex* is a variant of [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") maintained by [AmyBSOD](/wiki/User:Bluescreenofdeath "User:Bluescreenofdeath"). It adds more variety by enabling all role, race, gender, and alignment combos for playing, allowing many more monsters and items to be randomly generated, and adding new monsters from other *NetHack* variants as well. Apart from a bunch of monster shoes from [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") it tries to remain true to the spirit of dNetHack.

It is playable on the [em.slashem.me](/wiki/Em.slashem.me "Em.slashem.me") server.

### [DynaHack](/wiki/DynaHack "DynaHack")

| DynaHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Home page](http://tung.github.io/DynaHack/), [GitHub page](https://github.com/tung/DynaHack)
- formerly maintained by [Tungtn](/wiki/User:Tungtn "User:Tungtn")
- last update 18 February 2016
- current version 0.6.0
- variant of [NitroHack](/wiki/NitroHack "NitroHack") and [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") |

*DynaHack* is an experimental variant of *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It mainly merges the new content and challenges of [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") (up to version 4.1.1) onto [NitroHack](/wiki/NitroHack "NitroHack") as a base, with its new resizable ASCII interface. It also includes the save system, many bug fixes and selected interface changes from [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4"), magical equipment from [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), changes from other variants, and some original changes to add variety and fairness to the gameplay.

It can be played online via [ssh nethack@hardfought.org](ssh://nethack@hardfought.org) (USA) [public server](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") (discussion in [#hardfought](irc://libera.chat/#hardfought) on [Libera](/wiki/Libera "Libera")).

### [NetHack brass](/wiki/NetHack_brass "NetHack brass")

| NetHack brass                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Archived home page](http://wayback.archive.org/web/20071115145609/http://www11.cds.ne.jp/~youkan/nethack/index_e.html)
- formerly maintained by [紅茶羊羹](https://twitter.com/youkan700) a.k.a. [Kōcha Yōkan](http://www.maroon.dti.ne.jp/youkan/)
- current version 081221
- variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

Coming from Japan, *NetHack brass* (developed by Kōcha Yōkan, which roughly translates to "tea-flavored [gelatinous cube](/wiki/Gelatinous_cube "Gelatinous cube")") is lesser known among *NetHack* players who do not speak Japanese. The game is in English but most of the community uses Japanese. NetHack brass adds no new races or roles, but it has a few new [items](/wiki/Item "Item") and a redesigned [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"). Its major features include the new #[skills](/wiki/Skills_\(NetHack_brass\) "Skills (NetHack brass)") system and tweaks to how heroes gain [experience levels](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") and [attributes](/wiki/Attribute "Attribute"). [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") is now filled with shops, while the top of [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban "Sokoban") offers prizes but permits the player to choose one and only one.

Despite the many changes in this variant, they do not feel so drastic, and NetHack brass feels more like [vanilla](/wiki/Vanilla "Vanilla") than the other variants.

### [NetHack: The Next Generation](/wiki/NetHack:_The_Next_Generation "NetHack: The Next Generation")

| NetHack: The Next Generation                                                                                                                                                                                |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Archive page](http://www.juiblex.co.uk/nethack/TNG.html)
- formerly maintained by Sebastian Klein and Bill Foust
- current version 1.0
- variant of [NetHack 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.3 "NetHack 3.1.3") |

*NetHack: The Next Generation* was a variant that has mostly fallen into disuse. TNG contains several strange new monsters and items, but is mostly remembered for the Geek class and the Douglas Adams themed monsters.

### [NitroHack](/wiki/NitroHack "NitroHack")

| NitroHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Archive of nitrohack.org](http://web.archive.org/web/20140517210041/http://nitrohack.org/), [project's GitHub page](https://github.com/DanielT/NitroHack/)
- formerly maintained by [Daniel Thaler](https://github.com/DanielT) a.k.a. [DanielT](/wiki/User:DanielT "User:DanielT")
- current version 4.0.4
- variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

*NitroHack* is a variant that aims to be a modern, network-capable fork of the classic game.

It features native netplay via its client (connect to *nitrohack.org*), and can support any client that can speak its new JSON-based protocol; a web client is planned. It uses an enhanced version of the [Curses interface](/wiki/Curses_interface "Curses interface"), has fully remappable key controls and character display, dungeon overview, and UI improvements from [AceHack](/wiki/AceHack "AceHack"). It also records full play logs, allowing players to view interactive replays of current and finished games. Its savegame code is notoriously buggy, though.

Development of NitroHack has stopped in favor of [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4"), itself a merge of AceHack and NitroHack. NitroHack also lives on in [DynaHack](/wiki/DynaHack "DynaHack"), another modern variant that is based on NitroHack. Both NetHack 4 and DynaHack thankfully fix the buggy savegame code of NitroHack.

### [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM")

| SLASHTHEM                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project's Github page](https://github.com/Soviet5lo/SlashTHEM)
- maintained by [Soviet5lo](/wiki/User:Soviet5lo "User:Soviet5lo")
- current version 0.9.7
- variant of [SLASH'EM Extended](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_Extended "SLASH'EM Extended") |

SlashTHEM ([github page](https://github.com/Soviet5lo/SlashTHEM)) is a variant of [Slash'EM Extended](/wiki/Slash%27EM_Extended "Slash'EM Extended") version 75. Its name is short for "Super Lotsa Added Stuff Hack—The Heavily Extended Mod". It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") server.

### [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack")

| SpliceHack                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [GitHub](https://github.com/NullCGT/SpliceHack)
- maintained by [AntiGulp](/wiki/User:Agulp "User:Agulp") a.k.a. NullCGT
- current version 1.2.0
- variant of [NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack") development version |

*SpliceHack* is a variant that was unintentionally released only a few hours before 3.6.1; it is now based on NetHack 3.7.0.

The main goal of SpliceHack is to make the game much more interesting and dynamic by adding additional content, while being as accessible as possible to those used to playing vanilla *NetHack*. A secondary goal is to maintain a level of balance and difficulty that is similar to vanilla. The variant is updated frequently, and YANIs are actively incorporated into the code. The author has described it as what SLASH'EM might look like if SLASH'EM had been based on [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1").

SpliceHack features a large number of new monsters, items, locations, and effects. It also includes a number of extensible and dynamic features, such as monsters that are random fusions of other monsters and allowing pets to gain resistances through corpses. It can be played on the [Hardfought](/wiki/Hardfought "Hardfought") server.

During 2021, SpliceHack was rewritten on a clean 3.7.0-dev base and discarded some perennially troublesome features, culminating in the release of version 1.0.0. Development and bugfix support later ended in 2022.

### [UnNetHackPlus](/wiki/UnNetHackPlus "UnNetHackPlus")

| UnNetHackPlus                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Project's GitHub page](https://github.com/mkoniecz/UnNetHackPlus)
- formerly maintained by [Bulwersator](/wiki/User:Bulwersator "User:Bulwersator") a.k.a. [mkoniecz](https://github.com/mkoniecz)
- current version 4.8.0
- variant of [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") |

*UnNetHackPlus* is a variant whose main intent was to put more randomness, challenges and fun into UnNetHack (i.e. the same intent as UnNetHack). UnNetHackPlus incorporates many changes from other variants and patches as well as its own to form into a fun and balanced variant. It is the only known variant that outright removes [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban "Sokoban"). Its biggest improvements live on, having been implemented in UnNetHack and [DynaHack](/wiki/DynaHack "DynaHack").

### [3.4.3-NAO](/wiki/Nethack.alt.org#NetHack_3.4.3_NAO "Nethack.alt.org")

| 3.4.3-NAO                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - [Info and source code](http://alt.org/nethack/naonh.php)
- formerly maintained by [Paxed](/wiki/User:Paxed "User:Paxed")
- last update 31 July 2014
- variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") |

*[nethack.alt.org](/wiki/Nethack.alt.org "Nethack.alt.org")*, commonly abbreviated to NAO, is one of the oldest *NetHack* public servers, and by far the most popular. For many years, they maintained their own variant of *NetHack*, based on [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"). It is meant to provide identical gameplay to vanilla 3.4.3. The changes they do include are bugfixes, interface improvements, removal of exploits, changes to allow tracking more statistics, a few popular patches, and minor miscellaneous improvements. It was long regarded as the best one to use if you wanted something as similar as possible to vanilla NetHack 3.4.3 but with the bugs fixed. However, it has largely been displaced by [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"), which incorporates all of the bugfixes and nearly all of the quality-of-life improvements.

After the release of 3.6.1, alt.org stopped hosting and updating it. It can still be played on [hardfought.org](/wiki/Hardfought.org "Hardfought.org"). The source, for the time being, remains available at <http://alt.org/nethack/naonh.php>.

## Historically significant patches

### [Biodiversity patch](/wiki/Biodiversity_patch "Biodiversity patch")

The [biodiversity patch](http://web.archive.org/web/20041209022619/http://userfs.cec.wustl.edu/~naw1/nh/nh_bio.html) by Nicholas Aodhagan Webb adds several monsters to the game, adjusts some monster behaviors and adds a few other features. This patch is about populating the [dungeon](/wiki/Dungeon "Dungeon") with monsters, not about changing the dungeon. It even adds more [trees](/wiki/Tree "Tree").

Some of the changes have a basis in [reality](/wiki/Real_life "Real life") (like echolocation for [bats](/wiki/Bat "Bat")), but there are also some serious nasties, including the [disintegrator](/wiki/Disintegrator "Disintegrator") and the [goldbug](/index.php?title=Goldbug\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Goldbug (page does not exist)").

### [Convict patch](/wiki/Convict_patch "Convict patch")

This patch adds the Convict, a [role](/wiki/Role "Role") more difficult than the [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist"). A large number of variants include this patch.

### [Lethe patch](/wiki/Lethe_patch "Lethe patch")

The [Lethe patch](http://web.archive.org/web/20080208181124/http://e-wire.net.au/~eb_mykae/) by Michael Clarke seems to be only a minor change to the game, before you reach [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa"). There you find the River Lethe which leads you into a very different [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom").

There are many new scares down there. If you are sufficiently powerful, then you can fight through it all, but it will be far more difficult than the boring and relatively benign [mazes](/wiki/Maze "Maze") of vanilla. Type carefully, and do not step into the river that causes [amnesia](/wiki/Amnesia "Amnesia"). At [Moloch's Sanctum](/wiki/Moloch%27s_Sanctum "Moloch's Sanctum"), the [high priest](/wiki/High_priest "High priest") of Moloch is [Cthulhu](/wiki/Cthulhu "Cthulhu")...

These days, more players choose [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") 0.0.7E7, which has most of the new items and monsters from this patch, but not the changed levels. Until the levels are integrated, one can play **[SLethe](/wiki/SLethe "SLethe")** which includes the new levels. There is a 0.0.7E7F3 SLethe playground on [em.slashem.me](/wiki/Em.slashem.me "Em.slashem.me").

### Infidel patch

The [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel") patch adds a role that specializes in offensive magic, with some similarities to Priests, and to Flame Mages from SLASH'EM. They can be humans or orcs; like Priests, they have a random pantheon, but Infidels always follow Moloch. The Infidel role offers a slightly unusual game, as they start with the Amulet of Yendor and are initially tasked with returning it to Moloch's Sanctum. There are a number of other quirks as well. The variants [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") incorporate this patch.

## See also

- [NetHack in other languages](/wiki/NetHack_in_other_languages "NetHack in other languages")
- [List of forks of the official *NetHack* repository on GitHub](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/network/members)
- [List of vanilla *NetHack* 3.4.3 forks on GitHub](https://github.com/Vanilla-NetHack/NetHack-3.4.3/network/members)
- [Patches](/wiki/Patch "Patch")

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*" There are probably other "historically significant patches" floating around out there that aren't documented here; the Bard Patch comes to mind."*
html:
Variant

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
The history of NetHack variant development in all its convoluted glory, as of February 2023. Black arrows indicate direct descent from a whole codebase; gray indicate inspiration or scattered features copied in.

A variant (also sometimes known as a fork, mod, or patchset) is a copy of NetHack to which substantial code changes have been made.

Most variants make changes to the gameplay, but this isn't a requirement: NitroHack, for instance, is a variant which makes huge code changes but does not change gameplay at all.

The NetHack General Public License allows anyone to create a variant, provided that they use the same license. Then, features from that variant may be reused in other variants!

Variants are distinct from patches. A variant typically contains a large amount of changes and has a broader goal, whereas a patch does one specific thing and contains only the changes required to make it work. Some variants were formed by applying multiple existing patches to the vanilla source code.

A variant is either distributed as a very large patch against vanilla NetHack (uncommon nowadays), or as a separate source code distribution such as a public Git repository.

All variants to date have the same overall goal that vanilla NetHack does: to enter Gehennom, retrieve the Amulet of Yendor, and bring it to the Astral Plane.

If you are thinking about making a variant, consider consulting active variant developers on Libera for advice and early feedback on your ideas.

Contents

  • 1 Actively developed variants
    • 1.1 dNetHack
    • 1.2 EvilHack
    • 1.3 FIQHack
    • 1.4 GnollHack
    • 1.5 notdNetHack
    • 1.6 notnotdNetHack
    • 1.7 Slash'EM Extended
    • 1.8 UnNetHack
    • 1.9 xNetHack
    • 1.10 Hack'EM
  • 2 Maintained variants
    • 2.1 GruntHack
    • 2.2 NetHack 4
    • 2.3 NetHack Fourk
    • 2.4 SLASH'EM
    • 2.5 SporkHack
    • 2.6 3.4.3-HDF
  • 3 Unmaintained variants
    • 3.1 AceHack
    • 3.2 DNHslex
    • 3.3 DynaHack
    • 3.4 NetHack brass
    • 3.5 NetHack: The Next Generation
    • 3.6 NitroHack
    • 3.7 SlashTHEM
    • 3.8 SpliceHack
    • 3.9 UnNetHackPlus
    • 3.10 3.4.3-NAO
  • 4 Historically significant patches
    • 4.1 Biodiversity patch
    • 4.2 Convict patch
    • 4.3 Lethe patch
    • 4.4 Infidel patch
  • 5 See also

Actively developed variants

These are variants that have added new features (not just bugfixes) in the last year.

dNetHack

dNetHack
  • Project's GitHub page
  • maintained by Chris
  • current version 3.23.0
  • variant of nethack.alt.org version of NetHack 3.4.3

dNetHack is a variant that does five main things: it greatly increases the number of artifacts, implements new monsters, re-organizes and expands the dungeon, attempts to re-balance armors, item appearances, and intrinsics to make more choices viable in the late game, and replaces the Elbereth mechanic with warding signs. It also incorporates the Pirate and Convict patches, and makes a few minor changes in existing classes and items.

Most new artifacts have custom effects and/or invocations. Most new monsters have new attacks or other code support. Dungeon changes include: multi-level alignment “quest” branches, additional side branches off the main dungeon, and a shortened Gehennom, with demon lairs randomly drawn from a small pool and fewer straight-up maze levels.

dNetHack incorporates code from many other variants and patches, such as SLASH'EM, and implements many YANIs from this wiki and from rec.games.roguelike.nethack.

Discuss the variant at irc://libera.chat/dnethack. It is playable at hardfought.


EvilHack

EvilHack
  • GitHub
  • maintained by K2
  • current version 0.8.3
  • variant of NetHack 3.6.7 post-release version

EvilHack is a variant based on NetHack 3.6.7.

EvilHack was designed from the outset to be a much more difficult game to win than vanilla NetHack. The inspiration for this game mainly comes from the variants GruntHack and SporkHack, incorporating many of the same features that make those variants difficult in their own right. Some of those features have remained the same (for example, SporkHack's reflection changes), but many have been altered to set them apart and provide the player with a new experience. Elements from other variants have been included as well, such as from Slash'EM, SpliceHack, UnNetHack, and xNetHack. There is also a significant amount of custom content that has been developed that is not found in any other variant. More custom content will be added as development continues, mainly in the way of optional branch quests.

EvilHack features new races and roles, new items (including object materials and object properties), an improved monster AI, a revamped Gehennom, several new monsters, and adds exciting and challenging experiences to virtually every aspect of vanilla NetHack. It can be played on the Hardfought server.

FIQHack

FIQHack
  • Project's GitHub page
  • maintained by FredrIQ a.k.a. FIQ
  • current version 4.3.1
  • variant of NetHack 4

FIQHack is a variant of NetHack 4 that has 3 main focuses: improving convenience and quality of life, improving monster AI and behaviour, and improving monster/player symmetry (i.e. making things behave the same for both). Aside from this, there have also been various other gameplay tweaks, as well as improvement of code quality.

A comprehensive changelog of every notable change in FIQHack can be found in its article.

GnollHack

GnollHack
  • Project's GitHub wiki page
  • maintained by Sound Mind Games
  • current version 4.1.3.16
  • variant of NetHack 3.6.2


GnollHack is a variant of NetHack 3.6.2 developed by Sound Mind Games, a Finnish nonprofit organization. It adds numerous monsters and items, changes spellcasting, and adds Gnolls as a playable race (replacing Gnomes).

notdNetHack

notdNetHack
  • Project's GitHub page
  • maintained by Demo
  • current version 2024.05.15 (date format)
  • variant of dNetHack

notdNetHack is a dNetHack fork that seeks to add more depth to the existing content of dNetHack while balancing and trimming out some of its points of failure. notdNetHack attempts to add fully complete features and content that feel like they belong with the existing dNetHack base while not being afraid to be different.

It is playable on the em.slashem.me and hardfought.org servers.

notnotdNetHack

notnotdNetHack
  • Project's Codeberg page
  • maintained by Noisytoot
  • current version 2024.05.15 (date format)
  • variant of notdNetHack

notnotdNetHack is a variant of notdNetHack.

It can be played on the Hardfought server.

Slash'EM Extended

Slash'EM Extended
  • maintained by Bluescreenofdeath a.k.a. Amy or AmyBSOD
  • current version 2.8.9
  • variant of SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2

Slash'EM Extended is a variant of SLASH'EM.

Compared to SLASH'EM, Slash'EM Extended contains many new roles and races for the player to choose from, many new special levels, a lot of new monsters, and other changes (similar goals to the original SLASH'EM, which also aimed at adding lots of stuff, so this has even more). The main dungeon is a bit shorter in Slash'EM Extended than in SLASH'EM but the Gehennom is longer (making their lengths more like in vanilla NetHack), and the demon/devil lairs appear in a random order.

UnNetHack

UnNetHack
  • Official blog, Github page
  • maintained by Patric Müller a.k.a.Bhaak
  • current version 6.0.8
  • variant of NetHack 3.6.6

UnNetHack is a variant whose main intent is to put more randomness, challenges and fun into NetHack. UnNetHack incorporates many changes from other variants and patches as well as its own to form a fun and balanced variant. In the era of NetHack 3.4.3, it was described as “how NetHack would look today if the DevTeam didn't stop releasing”, but then the DevTeam did keep releasing, and brought in content from UnNetHack to boot. It is the most famous and popular of the actively developed variants, and frequently shares with and borrows from other variants.

Discuss the variant at irc://libera.chat/unnethack.

It features more levels, several UI improvements, and a lot of game play related changes. It can be played on the Hardfought server.

xNetHack

xNetHack
  • Project GitHub
  • maintained by aosdict a.k.a Phol ende wodan
  • current version 8.0.0
  • variant of NetHack 3.7.0 development version

xNetHack is the first variant to be based on NetHack 3.7.0.

Its main goals are to fix balance problems in vanilla and remove sources of frustration, as well as experimenting with YANIs from the community. It also follows a unique development model of remaining up-to-date with the latest code added to vanilla, rather than being based on a static release; consequently, new features and improvements in vanilla always get included in xNetHack soon after they are added.

Some of its features include special rooms in maze levels, an overhauled spellcasting system, several new conducts, and several UI enhancements. It can be played on the Hardfought server.

Hack'EM

Hack'EM
  • GitHub
  • maintained by malor
  • current version 1.3.1
  • variant of Evilhack post-release version

Hack'EM is a variant based on Evilhack.

It can be played on the Hardfought public server.

Maintained variants

These variants haven't added any new features in the past year, but someone is still fixing bugs.

GruntHack

GruntHack
  • Home page, updated/maintained version
  • maintained by SGrunt, then later K2 and Tangles
  • current version 0.3.0
  • variant of NetHack 3.4.3

GruntHack is a variant intended to extend and enhance the game's existing behavior rather than altering it in any thoroughly substantial way, such as objects of the same object type being made from different materials and occasionally possessing non-standard powers, monsters having different races and using more tactics when fighting other monsters, and more intelligent pet behavior.

Though it enables the player to become significantly more powerful than in vanilla, a number of its changes add significant challenges to the early and late game, making it one of the most difficult variants.

There are public servers at ssh nethack@hardfought.org (USA) and ssh slashem@slashem.me.

NetHack 4

NetHack 4
  • Home page and repository
  • maintained by Ais523
  • current version 4.3-beta2
  • variant of AceHack and NitroHack (merged)

NetHack 4 is a merge of AceHack and NitroHack, and the official successor to both projects. It aims for gameplay similar to NetHack but with an improved interface. It combines the interface improvements and gameplay changes of AceHack (see its section) with the persistent inventory, larger message box, new status display, new options interface, fully remappable keys, new main menu and other features of NitroHack.

It can be played online on its public server using telnet nethack4.org or ssh nethack43@nethack4.org (password "nethack43") or via ssh nethack@hardfought.org (USA).

For command-line Git access, use git clone nethack4.org/media/nethack4.git.

NetHack Fourk

NetHack Fourk
  • github page
  • maintained by Jonadab
  • current version 4.3.0.5
  • variant of NetHack 4

NetHack Fourk is an experimental fork of NetHack 4. It has four main types of changes: balance adjustments and formula tweaks; differentiation of similar monsters, objects, and levels; consolidation of boring things; and monster letter reorganization. A lot of game mechanics work slightly differently than players tend to be used to. See the changelog for details.

It can be played on the Hardfought server.

SLASH'EM

SLASH'EM
  • Home page
  • maintained by Warren Cheung a.k.a. wacko
  • current version 0.0.8E0F1
  • variant of NetHack 3.4.3

Slash'EM or SLASH'EM, officially SuperLotsaAddedStuffHack - Extended Magic, used to be the foremost variant. This game and its ancestor variants are now part of vanilla NetHack's game history, because of the reuse of certain SLASH'EM code in NetHack 3.3.0.

SLASH'EM puts more effort into killing the hero; plenty of games end on dungeon level 1. There are more than plenty of new monsters, items and magic. The dungeon features several new one-level dungeon branches for the hero to die in. Three new portals lead to quests for artifact keys. The player also has a larger choice of races and roles than in vanilla, and that alone is enough to make an experienced NetHack player rethink strategy.

SLASH'EM started as a combination of two other variants, SLASH and the Wizard Patch. In turn, SLASH was a merger of and addition to NetHack Plus and NetHack--.

SLASH'EM recently switched from 'unmaintained' to 'maintained' status, with the advent of several recent commits that have addressed several bugs. The updated/maintained version can be played on the Hardfought server. An older, unmaintained version can be found at em.slashem.me.

SporkHack

SporkHack
  • Archived home page, github source
  • maintained by Derek S. Ray, then later K2 and Tangles
  • current version 0.7.0
  • variant of NetHack 3.4.3

SporkHack is a variant actively developed and tested until December 2011; development was started up again in July of 2017 by community members Tangles and K2. The stated purpose of the variant is to try to bring more challenge to the vanilla game for experienced players, as well as to make things less boring for all players. A patch and a Windows binary are available from the home page; the patch can be applied to a standard NetHack 3.4.3 distribution. SporkHack contains "more interesting" Caveman and Knight roles, and a number of balance adjustments throughout the game to spells, monsters and items... as well as intangibles such as the "to hit" formula. There are also cosmetic changes, for example the master lich is a green L.

Latest development of SporkHack includes bugfixes and functionality enhancement; no changes affecting gameplay or the original author's intent have been made at this time. The repository for version 0.7.0 can be found on GitHub.

The latest developed version (0.7.0) can be played online at the hardfought.org public server via ssh nethack@hardfought.org (discussion in #hardfought on Libera). The older version (0.6.3) can be played online on the em.slashem.me public server using ssh slashem@slashem.me.

3.4.3-HDF

Not a seperate variant per se, but a maintained version of 3.4.3-NAO hosted on hardfought which still gets bug fixes as needed.

Unmaintained variants

These variants aren't being updated at all. Some of them may still have lots of players.

AceHack

AceHack
  • Source code Git repository
  • formerly maintained by Ais523
  • current version 3.6.0
  • variant of NetHack 3.4.3

AceHack is a variant of NetHack that has similar gameplay to NetHack 3.4.3 but an improved interface, e.g. walking into doors opens them automatically, background colors to distinguish tame/peaceful/hostile monsters and stairs under items, describing what's under the cursor while moving it in farlook, and warning before moving into lava. It also includes gameplay changes such as rerolling for items and attributes during character generation, auto-identifying some items under circumstances where the identity is unambiguous, making floating eyes unhittable instead of paralyzing, replacing Stormbringer's disabling of the peaceful attack warning prompt with aggravate monster when wielded, and replacing map and item identity amnesia with draining of skill and spell training.

Development of AceHack has stopped in favor of NetHack 4, itself a merge of AceHack and NitroHack.

As of July 2022, AceHack can be played on the Hardfought server.

DNHslex

DNHslex
  • Project's GitHub page
  • maintained by Bluescreenofdeath
  • current version 3.16.1
  • variant of dNetHack

DNHslex is a variant of dNetHack maintained by AmyBSOD. It adds more variety by enabling all role, race, gender, and alignment combos for playing, allowing many more monsters and items to be randomly generated, and adding new monsters from other NetHack variants as well. Apart from a bunch of monster shoes from SLASH'EM it tries to remain true to the spirit of dNetHack.

It is playable on the em.slashem.me server.

DynaHack

DynaHack
  • Home page, GitHub page
  • formerly maintained by Tungtn
  • last update 18 February 2016
  • current version 0.6.0
  • variant of NitroHack and UnNetHack

DynaHack is an experimental variant of NetHack. It mainly merges the new content and challenges of UnNetHack (up to version 4.1.1) onto NitroHack as a base, with its new resizable ASCII interface. It also includes the save system, many bug fixes and selected interface changes from NetHack 4, magical equipment from GruntHack, changes from other variants, and some original changes to add variety and fairness to the gameplay.

It can be played online via ssh nethack@hardfought.org (USA) public server (discussion in #hardfought on Libera).

NetHack brass

NetHack brass
  • Archived home page
  • formerly maintained by 紅茶羊羹 a.k.a. Kōcha Yōkan
  • current version 081221
  • variant of NetHack 3.4.3

Coming from Japan, NetHack brass (developed by Kōcha Yōkan, which roughly translates to "tea-flavored gelatinous cube") is lesser known among NetHack players who do not speak Japanese. The game is in English but most of the community uses Japanese. NetHack brass adds no new races or roles, but it has a few new items and a redesigned Gehennom. Its major features include the new #skills system and tweaks to how heroes gain experience levels and attributes. Minetown is now filled with shops, while the top of Sokoban offers prizes but permits the player to choose one and only one.

Despite the many changes in this variant, they do not feel so drastic, and NetHack brass feels more like vanilla than the other variants.

NetHack: The Next Generation

NetHack: The Next Generation
  • Archive page
  • formerly maintained by Sebastian Klein and Bill Foust
  • current version 1.0
  • variant of NetHack 3.1.3

NetHack: The Next Generation was a variant that has mostly fallen into disuse. TNG contains several strange new monsters and items, but is mostly remembered for the Geek class and the Douglas Adams themed monsters.

NitroHack

NitroHack
  • Archive of nitrohack.org, project's GitHub page
  • formerly maintained by Daniel Thaler a.k.a. DanielT
  • current version 4.0.4
  • variant of NetHack 3.4.3

NitroHack is a variant that aims to be a modern, network-capable fork of the classic game.

It features native netplay via its client (connect to nitrohack.org), and can support any client that can speak its new JSON-based protocol; a web client is planned. It uses an enhanced version of the Curses interface, has fully remappable key controls and character display, dungeon overview, and UI improvements from AceHack. It also records full play logs, allowing players to view interactive replays of current and finished games. Its savegame code is notoriously buggy, though.

Development of NitroHack has stopped in favor of NetHack 4, itself a merge of AceHack and NitroHack. NitroHack also lives on in DynaHack, another modern variant that is based on NitroHack. Both NetHack 4 and DynaHack thankfully fix the buggy savegame code of NitroHack.

SlashTHEM

SLASHTHEM
  • Project's Github page
  • maintained by Soviet5lo
  • current version 0.9.7
  • variant of SLASH'EM Extended

SlashTHEM (github page) is a variant of Slash'EM Extended version 75. Its name is short for "Super Lotsa Added Stuff Hack—The Heavily Extended Mod". It can be played on the Hardfought server.

SpliceHack

SpliceHack
  • GitHub
  • maintained by AntiGulp a.k.a. NullCGT
  • current version 1.2.0
  • variant of NetHack 3.7.0 development version

SpliceHack is a variant that was unintentionally released only a few hours before 3.6.1; it is now based on NetHack 3.7.0.

The main goal of SpliceHack is to make the game much more interesting and dynamic by adding additional content, while being as accessible as possible to those used to playing vanilla NetHack. A secondary goal is to maintain a level of balance and difficulty that is similar to vanilla. The variant is updated frequently, and YANIs are actively incorporated into the code. The author has described it as what SLASH'EM might look like if SLASH'EM had been based on NetHack 3.6.1.

SpliceHack features a large number of new monsters, items, locations, and effects. It also includes a number of extensible and dynamic features, such as monsters that are random fusions of other monsters and allowing pets to gain resistances through corpses. It can be played on the Hardfought server.

During 2021, SpliceHack was rewritten on a clean 3.7.0-dev base and discarded some perennially troublesome features, culminating in the release of version 1.0.0. Development and bugfix support later ended in 2022.

UnNetHackPlus

UnNetHackPlus
  • Project's GitHub page
  • formerly maintained by Bulwersator a.k.a. mkoniecz
  • current version 4.8.0
  • variant of UnNetHack

UnNetHackPlus is a variant whose main intent was to put more randomness, challenges and fun into UnNetHack (i.e. the same intent as UnNetHack). UnNetHackPlus incorporates many changes from other variants and patches as well as its own to form into a fun and balanced variant. It is the only known variant that outright removes Sokoban. Its biggest improvements live on, having been implemented in UnNetHack and DynaHack.

3.4.3-NAO

3.4.3-NAO
  • Info and source code
  • formerly maintained by Paxed
  • last update 31 July 2014
  • variant of NetHack 3.4.3

nethack.alt.org, commonly abbreviated to NAO, is one of the oldest NetHack public servers, and by far the most popular. For many years, they maintained their own variant of NetHack, based on NetHack 3.4.3. It is meant to provide identical gameplay to vanilla 3.4.3. The changes they do include are bugfixes, interface improvements, removal of exploits, changes to allow tracking more statistics, a few popular patches, and minor miscellaneous improvements. It was long regarded as the best one to use if you wanted something as similar as possible to vanilla NetHack 3.4.3 but with the bugs fixed. However, it has largely been displaced by NetHack 3.6.1, which incorporates all of the bugfixes and nearly all of the quality-of-life improvements.

After the release of 3.6.1, alt.org stopped hosting and updating it. It can still be played on hardfought.org. The source, for the time being, remains available at http://alt.org/nethack/naonh.php.

Historically significant patches

Biodiversity patch

The biodiversity patch by Nicholas Aodhagan Webb adds several monsters to the game, adjusts some monster behaviors and adds a few other features. This patch is about populating the dungeon with monsters, not about changing the dungeon. It even adds more trees.

Some of the changes have a basis in reality (like echolocation for bats), but there are also some serious nasties, including the disintegrator and the goldbug.

Convict patch

This patch adds the Convict, a role more difficult than the Tourist. A large number of variants include this patch.

Lethe patch

The Lethe patch by Michael Clarke seems to be only a minor change to the game, before you reach Medusa. There you find the River Lethe which leads you into a very different Gehennom.

There are many new scares down there. If you are sufficiently powerful, then you can fight through it all, but it will be far more difficult than the boring and relatively benign mazes of vanilla. Type carefully, and do not step into the river that causes amnesia. At Moloch's Sanctum, the high priest of Moloch is Cthulhu...

These days, more players choose SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7, which has most of the new items and monsters from this patch, but not the changed levels. Until the levels are integrated, one can play SLethe which includes the new levels. There is a 0.0.7E7F3 SLethe playground on em.slashem.me.

Infidel patch

The Infidel patch adds a role that specializes in offensive magic, with some similarities to Priests, and to Flame Mages from SLASH'EM. They can be humans or orcs; like Priests, they have a random pantheon, but Infidels always follow Moloch. The Infidel role offers a slightly unusual game, as they start with the Amulet of Yendor and are initially tasked with returning it to Moloch's Sanctum. There are a number of other quirks as well. The variants EvilHack and Hack'EM incorporate this patch.

See also

  • NetHack in other languages
  • List of forks of the official NetHack repository on GitHub
  • List of vanilla NetHack 3.4.3 forks on GitHub
  • Patches


A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

" There are probably other "historically significant patches" floating around out there that aren't documented here; the Bard Patch comes to mind."
